I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed  
policy-based loan to the Kingdom of Cambodia for subprogram 3 of the Inclusive Financial Sector 
Development Program. 
 
2.   The program is part of a long-term partnership between the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) and the Government of Cambodia to develop an efficient and stable finance sector and to 
increase financial inclusion. Subprogram 3 will build on the reforms achieved under subprograms 
1 and 2 by (i) providing mechanisms to improve access to credit for micro, small, and medium-
sized enterprises (MSMEs), which will facilitate recovery from the coronavirus disease (COVID-
19) pandemic and beyond; (ii) implementing reforms to enhance financial stability, including 
streamlining cross-sector institutional supervision and strengthening credit risk management; and 
(iii) upgrading financial  sector infrastructure by introducing innovative payment systems. 
 
II.  PROGRAM AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Background and Development Constraints 
 
3.  ADB approved the programmatic approach and a policy-based loan for subprogram 1 in 
October 2016 and for subprogram 2 in September 2019.1 Subprogram 1 provided the foundation 
for the government’s financial inclusion and financial stability initiatives and developed a basic 
framework for cross-sector supervision. Subprogram 2 focused on the adoption of a national 
financial inclusion strategy as well as key legislation, including the Trust Law, the e-Commerce 
Law, and the Consumer Protection Law. Under subprogram 3, the government has implemented 
the national financial inclusion strategy and key legislation adopted under subprogram 2, and 
launched several initiatives to increase access to finance, including Cambodia’s first-ever small 
and medium-sized enterprise (SME) public credit guarantee scheme (CGS). The government has 
also made significant strides to preserve financial stability and improve crisis management. 
 
4.  Development problem and economic performance. During 2015–2019, Cambodia’s 
gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  growth  averaged  7.1%  per  year.  This  steady  growth  was 
underpinned by high foreign direct investment (FDI) inflows, strong export performance, prudent 
fiscal policy, low risk of sovereign debt distress, increasing domestic demand, and stable inflation 
(which averaged just 2.3% a year). The exchange rate between the riel and the US dollar has 
been stable. This sustained economic progress helped the country attain lower middle-income 
status in July 2016. The Rectangular Strategy (Phase IV) adopted in September 2018, prior to 
the COVID-19 pandemic, acknowledges that maintaining a broad-based 7% economic growth 
rate will require structural reforms. These include further diversification of the narrow economic 
base (which is currently dominated by sectors that are at risk from automation of their labor-
intensive processes, such as agriculture, tourism, garments, and construction) and promotion of 
private sector development and employment.2 
 
5.  Impact  of  COVID-19. However,  in  2020,  the COVID-19  pandemic  caused  a  sharp 
deceleration in the main engines of Cambodia’s economy: tourism; construction; and garments, 
textiles, and footwear. The pandemic also threatens to undermine Cambodia’s progress in poverty 
reduction. As of December 2020, Cambodia’s household debt was about 29.2% of GDP, up from

6.  Financial sector. Solid economic growth before the pandemic also created a favorable 
environment for the financial sector to expand and become more competitive and integrated with 
local and international markets. The banking subsector is sound and has adequate capital buffers. 
Asset quality has remained stable, with a slight increase in the gross nonperforming loan ratio 
from 2.0% in 2019 to 2.1% in 2020,7 as has capital adequacy, which decreased from 24.0% in 
2019 to 23.2% in 2020. However, Cambodia’s financial sector remains narrow with the banking 
and  microfinance  subsectors  comprising  virtually  all  financial  sector  assets.  The  banking 
subsector represented about 85.0% ($50.3 billion) of total sector assets, while the microfinance 
subsector represented about 14.3% ($8.5 billion).8 In addition, liquidity and concentration risks, 
especially in real estate, are increasing.9 At the end of 2020, bank loans to the real estate sector 
(construction,  real  estate  activities,  and  mortgages  for  owner-occupied  housing)  stood  at  
$10.1 billion and microfinance institution (MFI) loans to the real estate sector were $0.26 billion. 
This represented about 26.3% of the total credit portfolio in the banking system (up from 24.8% 
in 2019), of which banks accounted for 97.3% and MFIs for 2.5%. Growth in exposure to real 
estate and construction sectors was especially rapid before the COVID-19 pandemic but has 
since had a slight downturn. Real estate credit in the banking subsector grew by 24.5% in 2020 
and 37.9% in 2019. Compounding the issue of increasing liquidity and concentration risks in real 
estate, FDI inflows to Cambodia’s real estate sector totaled $355.6 million in 2020, accounting for 
9.8% of total FDI inflows (footnote 8). 
 
7.  The  National  Bank  of  Cambodia  (NBC)  has  introduced  several  policy  measures  to 
enhance the resilience of the financial system and rein in credit growth, including increasing the 
paid-in capital requirement for commercial banks to $75 million, adopting the Basel III liquidity 
coverage ratio, strengthening credit risk grading and provisioning requirements, and instituting 
capital conservation buffers. However, more needs to be done to develop a more broad-based, 
inclusive, and sustainable financial sector. Subsectors that typically provide alternative channels 
of intermediation and long-term financing—leasing, capital markets, insurance, and pension 
funds—remain underdeveloped compared with the rest of the Association of Southeast Asian 
Nations (ASEAN). In addition, there are few alternatives to offset the perceived higher levels of 
credit risks associated with MSMEs. For example, there is a notable absence of CGSs and

8.  Financial inclusion and micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises. Cambodia has 
a low level of financial inclusion because lending is fragmented, with credit readily available in 
urban areas, while rural areas and women remain underserved.10 According to the 2014 census, 
of the total 513,753 enterprises in the country, MSMEs accounted for 99.8% and employed 71.8% 
of the national labor force, and micro enterprises accounted for 97.6% of the enterprises in the 
country.11 In 2015, 62% of the micro enterprises and 26% of the SMEs were owned by women.12 
The Cambodian economy is highly informal, with only 5% of all enterprises registered at the 
Ministry of Commerce (MOC) or at a provincial or municipal commerce division as of 2014.13 
There is limited availability of financing for business growth and development. MSMEs have 
limited access to finance, with only 17.7% of unregistered enterprises acquiring a loan or a line of 
credit from a financial institution as of 2014. The financing gap for MSMEs is estimated to be  
$7.7 billion ($4.2 billion for women-owned MSMEs and $3.5 billion for men-owned MSMEs).14 
The challenges facing women entrepreneurs are particularly severe, with only 3% having access 
to formal credit (footnote 12). Despite the high liquidity of the banking system, many banks have 
difficulty lending to MSMEs because they find it challenging to evaluate MSMEs’ creditworthiness. 
Banks usually rely on borrowers providing real estate as collateral, which MSMEs usually do not 
have. As a result, the majority of MSMEs resort to informal sources of borrowing for investment 
and working capital, an exclusion that is likely to be exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. 
 
9.  Binding constraints. The government recognizes that generating better jobs to sustain 
growth and raise income levels in line with its COVID-19 recovery plans depends on broadening 
financial intermediation to support economic diversification. To meet this objective, the following 
development constraints must be addressed: (i) limited financial inclusion because of a lack of 
reasonably priced credit in local currency and an absence of consumer protection mechanisms, 
(ii) lack of a functional financial stability framework, and (iii) weaknesses in key financial sector 
infrastructure relative to international standards. 
 
10.  Limited financial inclusion. Access to financial products and services for the poor is 
limited and financial literacy is low. Only 21.7% of the adult population has a bank account despite 
Cambodia’s high private credit-to-GDP ratios.15 Microinsurance and financing to MSMEs and 
small farmers are limited. Businesses, including those owned by women, are hampered by their 
inability to access long-term finance due to a lack of collateral, the absence of government support 
such as guarantees, and financial illiteracy (e.g., in bookkeeping, accounting, and preparation of 
business plans). Only 18% of Cambodians are considered financially literate; Cambodia ranked 
135th out of 144 economies in an Atlas and Standard & Poor’s survey on financial literacy and 
achieved a low score of 11.5 out of a total possible score of 21 in a survey commissioned by the

11.  Lack  of  a  functional  financial  stability  framework.  Cambodia’s  financial  stability 
framework is weak while risks to financial stability have increased because of the acceleration of 
credit growth, as well as potential liquidity risks owing to the COVID-19 pandemic and real estate 
lending. Financial instability disproportionately affects the poor with access to financial services 
because they are vulnerable to banking crises and the resulting disruptions to payment systems 
and bank closures. The poor are also indirectly impacted by instability in growth and inflation 
caused by an unstable financial sector. The increasing use of financial technology (fintech),

financial sector oversight and supervision among key government agencies, (ii) lack of protection 
for the growing depositor base, (iii) lack of a local currency domestic debt market as an alternative 
to bank debt (lowering the economy’s reliance on the banking subsector for credit), and (iv) lack 
of a formal cross-sector regulator of nonbank financial products.

Cambodia’s financial infrastructure is underdeveloped and restricts access to finance and market 
development. It has critical gaps that inhibit wider local and foreign stakeholder participation, and

Three limitations need to be addressed: (i) payment systems are outdated; (ii) implementing 
regulations for e-commerce, digital finance, and trust products do not exist; and (iii) compliance

B.  Policy Reform, ADB’s Value Addition, and Sustainability 
 
14.  The government’s reform agenda. The government considers its commitments under 
the ASEAN Economic Community Blueprint 2025 to be a catalyst for continued reforms of the 
domestic and external financial sector integration.23 Anchored in the FSDS (footnote 19), the 
government’s  reform  agenda  prioritizes  the  development  of  a  sound  financial  sector  that 
contributes to poverty reduction by supporting economic growth and increasing the poor’s access 
to finance. Specific goals include (i) the development of the nonbank subsector and capital market, 
(ii) alignment of regulations and supervision with international standards, (iii) the establishment of 
a formal crisis management mechanism, and (iv) financial inclusion. The National Financial 
Inclusion Strategy (NFIS), 2019–2025, which is at an early stage of implementation, identifies 
short-, medium-, and long-term interventions in inclusive finance and financial literacy.  
 
15.  Programmatic approach. The program supports three reform areas: (i) access to formal 
financial services for the poor, (ii) financial sector stability, and (iii) financial sector infrastructure. 
At the time of approval of subprogram 2, the government agreed to accomplish 17 indicative policy 
actions for subprogram 3. While all 17 were achieved, 15 policy actions are reflected in the policy 
design and monitoring framework. Two indicative policy actions on the preparation of draft laws 
on the deposit protection scheme and on the bank resolution regime were achieved and thus 
meet the requirements of the original indicative policy actions. They are being reviewed by the 
government to ensure that they are practicable under all local laws and regulations. These laws 
have become increasingly important in the context of the economic downturn brought about by 
the COVID-19 pandemic, and the government has requested the International Monetary Fund 
(IMF) to further review and improve these laws to ensure that they are aligned with international 
standards. In this regard,  ADB and the government  have agreed to strengthen these two 
indicative policy actions with their submission to the National Assembly and move them to the 
post-program partnership framework (P3F).24 This shift did not affect the expected outcome and 
outcome indicators.  A Trust Law implementing regulation was adopted, and female trustees were 
registered under the new nonfinancial trusts. The indicative policy action was revised to reflect a 
more important reform in subprogram 3 – the establishment of the trust regulator under the newly 
created Non-bank Financial Services Authority (NBFSA), which will supervise financial trusts 
when they are developed in the near future . There have been no significant revisions to the other 
policy actions, which are discussed in a supplementary linked document.25 The changes are 
reflected in the policy design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1).

introducing landmark government-backed credit-enhancing financial products, and establishing a 
framework for adequate consumer protection. Under subprogram 3, (i) the government continued

18.  In February 2020, the NBC awarded the ARDB a full commercial banking license. The 
ARDB adopted a 3-year business plan (2021–2023), which incorporates COVID-19 recovery 
measures, to better serve the agriculture sector and support the transition of subsistence farmers 
into agriculture entrepreneurs. Following the enactment of the Consumer Protection Law, the 
government adopted implementing regulations which, among others, established the National 
Commission  for  Consumer  Protection  under  the  new  General  Department  of  Consumer 
Protection,  Competition  and  Fraud  Prevention  at  the  MOC,  the  enforcement  agency.28 To 
encourage  the  use  of  microinsurance  by  the  underserved  segment  of  the  population,  the 
government licensed microinsurance operators, permitted banks to act as insurance agents, and 
designed tailored products such as insurance against breast cancer and discounted life insurance 
for women. As a result, women accounted for 55% of microinsurance clients as of 2020. 
 
19.  Small and medium-sized enterprise credit guarantees. The Ministry of Economy and 
Finance (MEF) established Cambodia’s first-ever public CGS, which is operated by the Credit 
Guarantee Corporation of Cambodia (CGCC), a state-owned enterprise, and provided $200 
million  in  capital.  The  CGS,  named  the  Business  Recovery  Guarantee  Scheme,  will  be 
implemented in two phases that will support MSMEs and large corporates through the COVID-19 
recovery period and beyond. Phase 1 (2021–2022) focuses on survival and preparation for 
COVID-19 recovery, during which time large corporates will also be eligible;29 and phase 2 (2023 
onward) will focus on recovery and economic diversification, during which only MSMEs will be 
eligible. The CGS will initially target all sectors, as well as gender, rural areas, and job creation.30 
A well-designed CGS will help to mitigate the collateral constraints of Cambodian SME borrowers, 
reduce the risks to banks of lending to SMEs (and hence unlock financing for the SMEs), and 
promote private sector development. The coverage of individual and corporate borrowers in the

play a critical role in managing financial crises. A law was also enacted to establish the NBFSA,

and SERC, to strengthen the effective management, control, and development of the nonbank

Cambodia’s  financial  sector.  The  NBC  issued  regulations  for  Bakong,32 a  successful  and

cashless transactions between retail customers of local banks and payment services providers.33

including among women. The National Assembly approved the Law on Government Securities, 
2020, an abrogation of the 2007 version, to align government securities operations with the Law

others, the issuance of local currency government debt securities, which will establish a yield

country’s capital market. To prepare for bond issuance, the government built the capacity of key 
agency officials through stakeholder consultations and workshops, and prepared a road map for 
issuance, registration, and trading.

26.  Lessons learned. ADB’s long engagement in Cambodia’s financial sector has provided 
three key lessons that have informed subprogram 3.41 First, financial sector development is a 
gradual process that requires proper sequencing. Key foundational reforms to the banking 
subsector must be in place before progressing to more complex reforms to the nonbank subsector. 
Second, government coordination and ownership of reforms articulated through a series of 
FSDSs are necessary to ensure that financial sector development is based on predetermined 
steps, with each one supported by interagency coordination to achieve broad support for reforms. 
Third, as financial services play a key role in supporting the growth of the real economy while 
promoting inclusive finance, a comprehensive reform approach is required to make the financial 
sector more inclusive.  
 
27.  ADB’s value addition to the program design and implementation. ADB provided 
technical assistance (footnote 36) that contributed directly to the implementation of the reforms 
under subprogram 3, including (i) the financial literacy program for the national school curriculum 
for university and investment professionals and for the agriculture sector; (ii) regulations for 
consumer protection and e-commerce; (iii) the design and legal and technical structuring of the 
CGS and CGCC; (iv) the fintech development road map; (v) development of a government bond 
market carried out jointly with the ASEAN Secretariat under the ASEAN Bond Market Initiative; 
and (vi) the dedicated MSME e-commerce training program. 
 
28.  Development partner coordination. ADB is the lead development partner supporting 
Cambodia’s financial sector and provides comprehensive support in coordination with some 
bilateral and multilateral development agencies. The IMF supports the government’s efforts to 
address elevated macro-financial risks by supporting the NBC on banking supervision and 
financial  stability,  monetary  policy  and  foreign  exchange  operations,  de-dollarization,  and 
strengthening of AML/CFT. ADB collaborated with the IMF on macroeconomic analysis and, 
through this program’s policy dialogue, on deposit protection, bank resolution, and COVID-19

C.  Expected Outcome of the Reforms 
 
29.  The impact of the reforms is demonstrated through three primary channels, as reflected 
in the policy design and monitoring framework: (i) the growth of the financial sector, which will 
lead to increased intermediation and private sector growth; (ii) strengthened consumer deposit 
protection, which will provide greater depositor confidence, as shown by the increased bank 
deposit share to GDP; and (iii) increased financial inclusion, which will give more people access 
to a growing financial sector. During 2015–2020, the ratio of total private sector credit of banks to 
GDP grew from 75.4% to 137.1%, the M2-to-GDP ratio increased from 72.4% to 124.5%,42 and 
the number of women with an account at a formal financial institution increased from 1.08 million 
to 2.68 million. Gross insurance premiums increased from $151.4 million in 2017 to $272.9 million 
in 2020. As a result of the reform progress made during the program, new outcome indicators 
were added: up to 10% of SME loans are expected to be guaranteed by CGCC to support  
COVID-19 recovery, and the launch of a new financial trust product will promote diversification of 
the financial sector. The program’s economic assessment estimates that the 3-year GDP increase 
that is expected from the financial inclusion reforms for 2021–2024 ranges from $198 million to 
$330 million.43 
 
D.  Development Financing Needs and Budget Support 
 
30.  The government has requested a concessional loan of $40 million from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources to help finance subprogram 3. The loan will have a 24-year term, including a 
grace period of 8 years; an interest rate of 1.0% per year during the grace period and 1.5% per 
year thereafter, and such other terms and conditions as set forth in the draft loan agreement. The 
size of the loan is based on Cambodia’s development financing needs as identified during country 
programming and strategy formulation, the development impact of the policy reform package, and 
the development spending arising from the reforms. In 2021, the fiscal deficit is expected to be 
$2.0 billion or 7% of GDP. Based on the Budget Law for 2021, financing needs at the national 
level are $2.30 billion, with $1.04 billion to be financed domestically and $1.26 billion from foreign 
financing (with $210.43 million in budget support).

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
32.  Governance.  The government is committed to enhancing good governance in its public 
financial management (PFM) by introducing international best practices and standards and 
transforming  its  PFM  systems  toward  result-based  fiscal  planning  and  decentralization. 
Governance has been at the core of Cambodia’s PFM reform strategy as reflected in the 
Rectangular  Strategy  (Phase  IV)  (footnote  2).  In  August  2020,  ADB  approved  a  sector 
development program for continued strengthening of subnational fiscal planning, PFM, and public 
administration,  which  supported  decentralization  and  deconcentration  reforms.  The  project 
component  established  the  National  School  of  Local  Administration  to  provide  sustainable 
capacity development for staff of subnational administrations.45  
 
33.  Poverty  and  social.  The  program  is  categorized  general  intervention  to  support 
sustainable economic growth and poverty reduction. The promotion of inclusive finance extends 
affordable formal financial services to the poor and rural microenterprises. Key reforms include 
pilot programs for financial literacy in the national school curriculum and for rural farmers, the 
implementation of the NFIS, including its monitoring and evaluation framework, and mitigating 
financial  risk  in  low-income  households  through  affordable  microinsurance.  Strengthened 
consumer protection and a dedicated public SME CGS targeting poorer entrepreneurs will instill 
consumer confidence and ensure that the underserved benefit from financial services and 
products. 
 
34.  Gender. Subprogram 3 is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. It targets the 
increased financial inclusion of women and sets gender equality targets for utilizing modern 
financial products. The government has achieved these through the implementation of the NFIS 
and has launched pilot programs for financial literacy in formal education, which benefits girls and 
boys. Of the teachers receiving financial literacy teacher training, 67% are women. The program 
to improve the financial literacy of the securities industry for university students and investment 
professionals includes women. A training of trainers program in financial literacy and basic 
cooperative management for rural farmers and agriculture cooperatives was attended by ARDB 
staff, 24% of whom were women. Cambodia’s first government-backed SME CGS prioritizes 
companies led by women and will provide a pathway for women’s access to finance from 
commercial banks. The MEF has made considerable efforts to raise awareness of the importance 
of  insurance  among  women-led  businesses  and  households  and,  as  a  result,  55%  of 
microinsurance clients in 2020 were female. The MEF has also registered five female trustees 
under the newly enacted trust scheme. The MOC rolled out a dedicated MSME e-commerce 
training program to a pool of trainers, 30% of whom were women, who will guide Cambodia's 
MSMEs and female entrepreneurs toward e-commerce success. The NBC’s fintech development 
road map includes a dedicated financial and digital literacy program aimed at women. Women 
will be the main beneficiaries of financial literacy and e-commerce reforms.

is classified category C for environment, involuntary resettlement, and indigenous peoples. The 
program is not expected to have any environmental or social safeguard impacts within the 
meaning of ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement.

Subprogram 3 will build on the reforms achieved under subprograms 1 and 2 by (i) providing mechanisms to improve access to credit for micro, small, and mediumsized enterprises (MSMEs), which will facilitate recovery from the coronavirus disease (COVID- 19) pandemic and beyond; (ii) implementing reforms to enhance financial stability, including streamlining cross-sector institutional supervision and strengthening credit risk management; and (iii) upgrading financial sector infrastructure by introducing innovative payment systems.
